items.title: Thursday Reading: Home Composting in the City
items.abstract: Home composting in the city, piecing together the fiscal deal’s effect on taxpayers, talking to other parents about guns and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

items.title: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tech Design Comics and Artificial Intelligence Money
items.abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include Internet technologies spreading into more industries, which Web sites share what information and the latest iPhone bug.

items.title: What Constitutes Good and Bad Web Design?
items.abstract: Well-crafted sites need to fulfill their functions efficiently and engagingly.

items.title: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
items.abstract: The city, which sat on the sidelines while its Southern sisters boomed, has found itself in the national spotlight, with economic gains and a newly found popularity.

items.title: Terrorists No Match for Single City Cop
items.abstract: The first novel by the “Law & Order” creator Dick Wolf, “The Intercept” provides a sense of insiderdom in an otherwise standard detective novel about a terrorist plot.

items.title: City’s Delayed Traffic Study to Guide Regulation of Uber Vehicles
items.abstract: The study, which was originally due at the end of November, aimed to assess the ride-hailing service’s effects on traffic congestion in Manhattan.

items.title: Airbnb Takes Its Case to U.S. Mayors Conference
items.abstract: Having tried to mobilize the public in its favor, Airbnb offers to collect $200 million in hotel taxes for cities.

items.title: Video Review: Chevy Volt Impresses With Tech, Design and Driving Pleasure
items.abstract: The second-generation Chevy Volt, a plug-in hybrid available this spring, is more efficient than its predecessor, looks better and is about $1,000 less expensive. It’s also fun to drive.
keywords: Chevrolet Division of General Motors Corp

items.title: Connectivity in New York City Schools
items.abstract: The Parents’ Association at the Bronx High School of Science writes that bandwidth has been capped in city schools but that a solution is now available.

items.title: Flood of Support After Bronx Councilman James Vacca Reveals on Twitter He Is Gay
items.abstract: The councilman, a Democrat, posted his coming out statement to Twitter on Friday afternoon.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: In a World of Fine Lines, Manchester City Tightens the Title Race
items.abstract: A game decided by the slightest of differences set the tone for a fierce battle for the Premier League between Liverpool and City (and perhaps Tottenham).

items.title: In Texas, Trump’s Visit Offers Two Views of a Border
items.abstract: President Trump used McAllen, Tex., as the backdrop for his border visit Thursday. It is a city of 142,000, a place of synagogues, country clubs and misperceptions.

items.title: As If by Design, Their Connection Was Inevitable
items.abstract: William Ackman had been given two nudges by two friends to reach out to Neri Oxman. He found they were both right.

items.title: Drone Scare Near New York City Shows Hazard Posed to Air Travel
items.abstract: The shutdown of Newark Liberty International Airport on Tuesday reminded travelers how vulnerable airports are to the threat of wayward drones.
keywords: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: How to Design a Home Gym That You’ll Actually Use
items.abstract: As the pandemic rages on, the safest place to work out is at home. Here’s how to create a personal gym you’ll want to spend time in.

items.title: They Had Reasons for Leaving the City. So Why Are Their Friends Mad?
items.abstract: When Covid hit, some New Yorkers abandoned the city for good. They left some angry friends.

items.title: The Plans for the World’s Next Largest City Are Incomplete
items.abstract: Delhi is growing far beyond the formal confines of the city, a case study in the complexity of what we call urbanization.

items.title: A Grim January Leaves Some New Yorkers Fearful for the City’s Future
items.abstract: New York is far safer and stronger than in the ’70s. But after a flood of sad news, many people are struggling to find grounds for optimism.
